qas.question: The "To Secure These Rights" findings wanted desegregation of which institution?
Which risk associated with serving was specifically highlighted by the findings?
What did the findings say occurred to an individual when he enters the armed services?

answers.text: surrenders some of the rights and privileges

qas.question: Discrimination that prevented minorities from serving their country to the best of their abilities was seen as what?
The "To Secure These Rights" findings did not want desegregation of which institution?
Which risk associated with serving wasn't specifically highlighted by the findings?

plausible_answers.text: surrenders some of the rights and privileges

qas.question: What did the findings say occurred to an individual when he leaves the armed services?
Discrimination that prevented minorities from serving their country to the best of their abilities wasn't seen as what?

context: To Secure These Rights also called for desegregation of the <a0_0><b4_0>Armed Forces<b4_0/><a0_0/>. "Prejudice in any area is an ugly, undemocratic phenomenon, but in the armed services, where all men run the risk of <a1_0><b5_0>death<b5_0/><a1_0/>, it is especially repugnant." The rationale was fairness: "When an individual enters the service of the country, he necessarily <a2_0><b6_0>surrenders some of the rights and privileges<b6_0/><a2_0/> which are inherent in American citizenship." In return, the government "undertakes to protect his integrity as an individual." Yet that was not possible in the segregated Army, since "any discrimination which…prevents members of the minority groups from rendering full military service in defense of their country is for them <a3_0>a <b7_0>humiliating badge of inferiority<b7_0/><a3_0/>." The report called for an end to "all discrimination and segregation based on race, color, creed, or national origins in…all branches of the Armed Services.":38–39
